--- execute: cache: false --- # Country Charts {#sec-country-charts} ::::: {#obj-chapter-template} :::: {.my-objectives} ::: {.my-objectives-header} Objective of this chapter ::: ::: {.my-objectives-container} I will display the yearly variations of the cantril ladder values for certain countries. My focus will be on German speaking countries (Austria, Germany, Switzerland) and on some major European countries. ::: :::: ::::: :::::{.my-r-code} :::{.my-r-code-header} :::::: {#cnj-show-eval-DACH} : Evolution of life evaluation for German speaking countries :::::: ::: ::::{.my-r-code-container} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ranking_2024 <- base::readRDS("data/whr-cantril/rds/whr_2011_2024.rds") ranking_2024 |> dplyr::filter( `Country name` == "Austria" | `Country name` == "Germany" | `Country name` == "Switzerland" ) |> country_selection_line_graph() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](03-country-charts_files/figure-html/show-eval-DACH-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: :::: ::::: :::::{.my-r-code} :::{.my-r-code-header} :::::: {#cnj-show-eval-european-countries} : Evolution of life evaluation for some European countries :::::: ::: ::::{.my-r-code-container} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ranking_2024 <- base::readRDS("data/whr-cantril/rds/whr_2011_2024.rds") ranking_2024 |> dplyr::filter( `Country name` == "Germany" | `Country name` == "France" | `Country name` == "Italy" | `Country name` == "Spain" | `Country name` == "Poland" ) |> country_selection_line_graph() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](03-country-charts_files/figure-html/show-eval-european-countries-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: :::: ::::: ## Glossary ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
term definition
Cantril Ladder The Cantril Ladder is a visual scale used to assess general life satisfaction. It asks respondents to evaluate their lives on a ladder from worst (bottom) to best (top) possible life, making it a simple tool to measure subjective well-being. This measure has been widely used in various studies and surveys, including the Gallup World Poll, which collects data from over 140 countries annually.
